25dcdac7-fe12-42ab-a33a-64f85481e1fd.description: An occupational therapy fieldwork educator possesses knowledge, supervision skills, and the ability to role model behaviors that are critical to the success of OT and OTA students and to the future of occupational therapy. This badge signifies advanced skills in this area including a deeper understanding of the fieldwork educator role, and knowledge of strategies to integrate learning theories and supervision models to provide high-quality educational opportunities during fieldwork experiences.
25dcdac7-fe12-42ab-a33a-64f85481e1fd.name: Fieldwork Educator Certificate

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Participation in a face to face continuing education course that takes place over 2 days (15 hours). Participants engage in four curricular modules that include: administration, education, supervision, and evaluation. In addition, participants engage in an analysis of strategies to support best practice in fieldwork education.

26c6195c-d8e2-4251-aa02-85ca73b45dee.description: Badge earners have undergone a process of leadership exploration, identification of core values, purpose, and personal mission, that lead to authentic and trusting relationships. Earners have a personal trajectory toward their preferred future and have leadership skills across six dimensions of intelligence to build capacity, have positive relationships, resolve conflicts and develop trust. Earners understand mentoring relationships and strategies for dealing with mentoring challenges.
26c6195c-d8e2-4251-aa02-85ca73b45dee.name: Mindful Path to Leadership Level I

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: To earn this badge, participants must complete three AOTA CE courses from the Mindful Path to Leadership Series--courses 1, 2 and 3.  When applicable, a score of 75% must be acheived on an assessment activity.

A Mindful Path to Leadership Series Module 1: Introduction.  This module supports the exploration of leadership from the inside out through the identification of core values, purpose, and person mission, leading to authentic and trusting relationships with others.  This module will help you to identify what you want to accomplish with your life and create a personal trajectory to put you on a mindful path toward your preferred future.

A Mindful Path to Leadership Series Module 2: Building Leadership Skills  This is the second module in the A Mindful Path to Leadership Series will help develop your leadership skills across six dimensions of intelligence to support your ability to build capacity in yourself and others, build positive relationships, resolve conflicts and develop trust within teams. This module builds upon the first module and will continue to facilitate your successful progression along your mindful path.

A Mindful Path Module 3: Mentoring and Leadership explores the roles/responsibilities associated with being a mentor and mentee, and identifies strategies for finding a mentor.  Structures and models for mentoring relationships and strategies for dealing with challenges  are explored.  Personality tests and professional development tools for  leadership skills are presented, and the importance of incorporating reflective practice and outcome evaluation in the mentoring process is addressed.

6a131d63-459a-4f60-914f-a736af206cf7.description: Earners have gained understanding of the role of the occupational therapy practitioner in home modification across the lifespan and with individuals of varying culture and disability status. Earners understand interdisciplinary team involvement, working with individuals transitioning from the hospital and with pediatric clients and families. Earners recognize the symbolic meaning and emotional attachment to the home. Earners have skills to assess the home environment and begin a private practice
6a131d63-459a-4f60-914f-a736af206cf7.name: Home Modifications

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Successful completion of 6 online courses and a score of 75% or higher: 1) I've Lived Here for 40 Years Without a Handrail" Meeting the Psychosocial Needs of Clients; 2)From Inspiration to Installation: The Search for Creative Ideas to Solve Home Mod Challenges; 3)Setting up a Home Modifications Business; 4)Enabling Design: A Person-Centered Approach; 5)Occupational Therapy’s Role in Assisting a Patient Transition from Hospital to Home; 6)Fundamentals of Pediatric Home Modifications

9ac2e6a4-a024-4d09-9501-3d970b7a367f.description: Earners participated in a 2.5 day training focusing on the ACOTE Accreditation Standards and program evaluation. Earner can critically evaluate an OT/OTA educational program for compliance with the standards, and has basic skills in conducting a thorough program evaluation including online review and simulated on-site data collection/interviewing. Earners are Certified Accreditation Evaluators and are qualified to conduct on-site program evaluations as a paper reviewer and as a co-evaluator.
9ac2e6a4-a024-4d09-9501-3d970b7a367f.name: Accreditation Evaluator

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Participation in 2.5 day training workshop

skills.name: In-depth Understanding Of The ACOTE Standards

148599c7-a217-4505-a906-bb4d7bdf6564.description: Earners of the Occupational Therapy Cancer Rehabilitation–Level 1 badge have successfully demonstrated an understanding of practice with individuals diagnosed with cancer including the basics of cancer rehabilitation and the impact of pscyhological and scoial issues surrounding the disease. Inaddition, earners understand the prevalence and different forms of cancer, are able to Identify common sites of metastasis of malignant tumors Identify basic cancer treatments and their common side effects
148599c7-a217-4505-a906-bb4d7bdf6564.name: Cancer Rehabilitation Level I

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Complete Occupational Therapy's Unique Contributions to Cancer Rehabilitation with a score of 75% or greater on the associated exam.
Complete Impact of Psychosocial Aspects of Cancer on Occupational Engagement with a score of 75% or greater on the associated exam.

skills.name: Complete Assessments For Anxiety And Depression
Identify 5 Stages In The Treatment Continuum
Identify Various Forms And Prevelence Of Cancer

923a0eb6-0f10-41f8-b627-d8c817c5c818.description: Earners of the Path to Leadership-Level II badge have undergone a process of leadership exploration, identification of core values, purpose, and personal mission as verified through the earning of the level I badge. The earning of the level II badge, the highest level in this series, demonstrates that the earner has gained the skills to expand their understanding of personal and professional responsibility in being a leader to include advocacy at systems, state and federal levels.
923a0eb6-0f10-41f8-b627-d8c817c5c818.name: Mindful Path to Leadership Level II

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Mindful Path to Leadership Level I

Series Module 4: A Mindful Path to Advocacy. This module supports the development of advocacy skills necessary to educate key stakeholders on the distinct value of occupational therapy to promote policies that practice. Learner outcomes include: The connection between health care policy and  OT·  Strategies for everyday practice  ·  Identify key stakeholders ·  Identify state and federal representatives and avenues to stay informed about policy and to advocate at the health-systems level.

skills.name: Identify Congressional Representatives Federal And State

f69275c9-e94b-4cbe-bd23-c3f57f6b0520.description: Earners of this badge demonstrate the basic knowledge and skills required to initiate and oversee a clinical fieldwork education program. Earners understand the roles and responsibilities of an OT practitioner within this role as well as the needs of the fieldwork student. Badge holders are able to work with academic institutions to ensure that systems and strategies are in place that meet ACOTE standards and provide positive student outcomes.
f69275c9-e94b-4cbe-bd23-c3f57f6b0520.name: Fieldwork Educator

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: FIELDWORK EDUCATION MODULE 1: Preparing to Become a Fieldwork Educator:  Reviews of the purpose of fieldwork education, identifies the benefits of providing fieldwork education, and an overview of level one and level two fieldwork for both the OT and the OTA student. Topics include: what students learn from and value in fieldwork educators as well as ACOTE standards they apply to fieldwork education.

FIELDWORK EDUCATION MODULE 2: Working with OT and OTA Students During Level I and Level II Fieldwork. Discusses educational requirements including introduction to ACOTE standards governing the fieldwork experience. Tools for self-assessment of readiness for the role of fieldwork educator are included as well as information about starting a fieldwork education program.

FIELDWORK EDUCATION MODULE 3: Fieldwork Career Paths:  Reviews the progression of the fieldwork educator in their role. Discussed in detail are the roles and responsibilities of the clinical site coordinator and the academic fieldwork coordinator. This module also covers how to maintain balance with the role of FW educator to ensure a satisfying and effective career trajectory.

skills.name: Level I And Level II FW Requirements

af11b2c8-59a6-40ea-8794-cb62aea7004b.description: Earners of the Occupational Therapy Low Vision level I badge have successfully demonstrated an understanding of the unique needs of older adults with low vision in safely and independently engaging in desired occupations. Earners of this badge understand the causes of low vision and the impact of low vision on occupational performance. They are also skilled in effective interventions including optical devices and strategies for environmental adaptations.
af11b2c8-59a6-40ea-8794-cb62aea7004b.name: Occupational Therapy Low Vision Level I

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Successful completion of course and a score of 75% or higher on associated exam: Low Vision in Older Adults: Foundations for Rehabilitation, 2nd Edition OR each of the four modules 1) Understanding Low Vision or Understanding Low Vision 2nd Ed ; 2) Selecting Low Vision Devices; 3) Modifying the Environment for Low Vision; and 4) Improving Performance for Low vision.

f899448a-cad8-4083-9dee-67ed555e6b3b.description: Earners of the Early Identification Badge have demonstrated the ability to identify developmental, educational, medical, psychosocial, and behavioral risk factors as part of the evaluation procedures of young children. Earners demonstrate knowledge of therapeutic strategies, techniques, and support networks that are designed to improve caregiver self-esteem, help caregivers understand infant cues and behaviors, and educate caregivers on developmental milestones.
f899448a-cad8-4083-9dee-67ed555e6b3b.name: Occupational Therapy Early Identification

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Successful completion of three online courses and a score of 75% or higher on associated exam: Contribution to Early Identification: Module 1 - Early Identification Practices, OT’s Contribution to Early Identification: Module 2 - Caregiver-Infant Relationship, Contribution to Early Identification: Module 3 - Autism Screening and Cultural Competency in Early Intervention,Contribution to Early Identification: Module 4 - Early Detection of Neuromuscular Disorders in Early Intervention Settings

c9d12821-e328-4f7e-b32f-c93cbe2b0b5e.description: Earners of the Occupational Therapy Cancer Rehabilitation–Level II badge have successfully demonstrated an understanding of practice with individuals diagnosed with cancer including the basics of cancer rehabilitation and the impact of pscyhological and scoial issues surrounding the disease. Level II earners will also have a strong working knowledge of the role of OT in working with individuals diagnosed with breast cancer and the impact of Lymphedema on occupational participation.
c9d12821-e328-4f7e-b32f-c93cbe2b0b5e.name: Cancer Rehabilitation Level II

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Cancer Rehabilitation Level I
Complete Lymphedema and Breast Cancer for OT Practitioners with a score of 75% or better on the associated exam.
Complete Lymphedema Basics with a score of 75% or better on the associated exam.

skills.name: Describe The Impact Of Breast Cancer On Performance Of Desired Occupations
Describe Treatment Interventions For Breast Cancer And Lymphedema
Understand Anatomy And Physiology Related To Lymphedema
Understand Cause And Course Of Breast Cancer

dd1bce14-84f4-40d9-afdb-d64307750d26.description: Earners of this badge have participated in formal Team Chair training. Earner now possesses the skills to lead a team during a program review and critically evaluate an OT/OTA educational program for compliance with the ACOTE Standards. The earner demonstrates advanced skills in communication, interviewing and program evaluation. Earners have gained practical experience in organizing and composing a Report of On-Site Evaluation
dd1bce14-84f4-40d9-afdb-d64307750d26.name: Accreditation Evaluator Team Chair

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Participation in a rigorous 2.5 day face to face workshop. Participation as an accreditation evaluator team member.

c4a84c8d-7e90-4e47-a127-cb0848cbc392.description: The third and final level of the Cancer Rehabilitation badges. In addition to the knowledge obtained through levels I and II badge content, earners of this badge can identify all aspects of the multi-dimensional nature, causes, and symptoms of cancer related fatigue (CRF) as well as identify useful assessments and interventions. Earners also understand the role of OT in addressing cancer associated cognitive impairment including assessment and intervention.
c4a84c8d-7e90-4e47-a127-cb0848cbc392.name: Cancer Rehabilitation Level III

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Cancer Rehabilitation Level I
Cancer Rehabilitation Level II

The Role of Occupational Therapy with Cancer Related Fatigue--This final module in the cancer series discusses the causes of cancer related fatigue (CRF) and what effect CRF has on occupational participation. You will learn how to assess and evaluate the multiple dimensions of CRF in order to assist with accurate intervention planning.  You will learn several interventions for managing CRF, including initiating and maintaining levels of physical activity and conserving and managing energy.

Cancer Associated Cognitive Impairment--addresses the impact of cancer related cognitive impairment on occupational performance. Currently, there are nearly 4 million cancer survivors with some form of cognitive impairment and this number is expected to grow as survival rates improve. OT practitioners may encounter cancer survivors throughout the continuum of care from diagnosis including pre-treatment, during treatment including palliative care, in survivorship or end of life.

skills.name: Choose Appropriate Assessments For Cancer Fatigue And Cognitive Impairment
Choose Appropriate Interventions To Address Cancer Related Fatigue And Cognitive Impairment
Understand Causes And Impact Of Cancer Related Fatigue And Cognitive Impairment
Understand Impact On Occupational Participation Of Cancer Related Fatigue And Cognitive Impairment

2df60d20-7776-4868-8558-535be520918a.description: Earners of the Enhanced Medical Rehabilitation Badge (EMR) recognize the positive outcomes association with a structured approach to applying the science of behavior change and principles of rehabilitation intensity to patients during OT. They understand that this evidence based approach better engages patients in their rehab, and encourages them to work harder to achieve meaningful and functional results using client selected activities.
2df60d20-7776-4868-8558-535be520918a.name: Enhanced Medical Rehabilitation Badge

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Occupational therapy practitioner and member of AOTA who has successfully completed the Enhanced Medical Rehabilitation CE course with an exam score of at least 75%

skills.name: Assist Clients In Understanding Purpose Of Rehab

e53dabdd-62ed-4ca8-9ce1-e980ddcac943.description: Earners have skills to execute a preventative occupational program for independent older adults. Earners understand the link between healthy eating, managing stress, spirituality and maintenance of healthy habits, routines and occupational behaviors. Earners understand the relationship between biological, social, pharmacological and lifestyle factors and their impact on sexuality as well as the relationship between community mobility and home safety for maintenance of occupational patterns.
e53dabdd-62ed-4ca8-9ce1-e980ddcac943.name: Lifestyle Modification

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: To earn this badge you must complete the following courses: Conceptual Foundations of Lifestyle Modification - LMS Unit 1 Needs Assessment and Group Leadership to Maintain Occupational Participation – LMS Unit 2 Routine, Occupational Balance and Health in Aging - LMS Unit 3 Transportation and Community Mobility to Support Occupational Engagement - LMS Unit 4 Stress and Inflammation Reduction for Older Adults - LMS Unit 5 Nutrition, Spirituality, and Sexuality for Productive Aging - LMS Unit 6

91edbd6f-4052-4fa6-9e7f-7588c324ee3c.description: Earners of the Occupational Therapy Driving Level I badge have successfully demonstrated an understanding of driving as an IADL impacted by impairments identified in evaluation of vision, physical ability, and cognition. Earners are familiar with the MODEM model and are able to develop resources to address service gaps and to identify a cost efficient service continuum. In addition, badge earners are able to educate families about transitioning to community mobility options.
91edbd6f-4052-4fa6-9e7f-7588c324ee3c.name: Occupational Therapy Driving and Community Mobility Level I

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Successful completion of two online courses: 1)AJOT CE: Predictive Value of the Cognitive Performance Test (CPT), and 2)Professional Reasoning: The Responsibility of All Occupational Therapists
Successful completion of this non-assessment course: The Ethical and Professional Obligation to Address Driving when Delivering Occupational Therapy Services

2b9211ae-0f4f-4cf0-bcc8-c06b5f3d0e3c.description: In addition to the criteria for the level I badge, earners of the Low Vision level II badge have successfully gained an understanding of low vision assessments. Earners of this badge understand the causes of low vision and the impact of low vision on occupational performance. They are also skilled in intervention planning, goal writing and documentation for individuals impacted by low vision.
2b9211ae-0f4f-4cf0-bcc8-c06b5f3d0e3c.name: Occupational Therapy Low Vision Level II

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Successful completion of course and a score of 75% or higher on associated exam: Low Vision in Older Adults: Foundations for Rehabilitation, 2nd Edition OR each of the four modules 1) Understanding Low Vision; 2) Selecting Low Vision Devices; 3) Modifying the Environment for Low Vision; and 4) Improving Performance for Low vision.
Successful completion of course and a score of 75% or higher on associated exam:  Low Vision Assessment for Occupational Therapy

skills.name: Intervention Planning And Intervention Based On Assessment Findings

e8817a9f-6e26-4625-84c1-27786f7960b8.description: Earners of the Autism badge have successfully demonstrated an understanding of practice with children on the autism spectrum. Earners of this badge are skilled at building an intentional relationship, using occupational therapy evaluation strategies, addressing sensory integration challenges, and planning intervention for praxis. Badge earners understand the value of using SIMPLE intervention to provide quality therapy for children on the autism spectrum.
e8817a9f-6e26-4625-84c1-27786f7960b8.name: Autism

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Complete Social Skills for Children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD)  with a score of 75% or greater on the associated exam.
Complete Autism Across the Lifespan, 4th Ed., Text & Exam Learn and Earn with a score of 75% or greater on the associated exam.

Those earning this micro credential prior to 3/21 did so by successfully completing the following comprehensive courses: Social Skills for Children with ASD, Autism Topics Part I: Relationship Building, Evaluation Strategies, and Sensory Integration and Praxis, Autism Topics Part II: Occupational Therapy Service Provision in an Educational Context and, Autism Topics Part III: Addressing Play and Playfulness When Intervening With Children With an Autism Spectrum Disorder

c0466e1a-d0e5-43e6-8a1c-164bc5197aca.description: Earners of the Occupational Therapy Driving Level II badge have obtained a basic understanding of low vision. This understanding includes knowledge of the anatomy of the eye, common eye diseases, the process of low vision care and the psychological and physical adjustments to low vision. Low vision is often a concern of aging drivers due to impact on ability to navigate in poor lighting, poor weather conditions, to see hazards quickly and see in the periphery.
c0466e1a-d0e5-43e6-8a1c-164bc5197aca.name: Occupational Therapy Driving and Community Mobility Level II

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Successful completion of the online course and a score of 75% or higher on associated exam: Understanding Low Vision

55bec0ab-b66d-4656-974c-7d6e7adf3ca8.description: The Occupational Therapy Driving Level III badge earner has also demonstrated the knowledge of strategies to address community mobility and driving across practice areas and settings including , schools, hospitals, rehabilitation centers, skilled nursing facilities and outpatient clinics. Earners are also knowledgeable about working with various disabilities or difficulties including developmental, physical, sensory processing, vision and mental health
55bec0ab-b66d-4656-974c-7d6e7adf3ca8.name: Occupational Therapy Driving and Community Mobility Level III

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Occupational Therapy Driving and Community Mobility Level I
Occupational Therapy Driving and Community Mobility Level II
Successful completion of course and a score of 75% or higher on associated exam: Driving & Community Mobility: Occupational Therapy Strategies Across the Lifespan

ba423002-ef7f-499e-8017-2b287dde708a.description: Elevate your practice and get the knowledge you need to be the best OT or OTA that you can be. Whether you’re looking to master a specific set of skills or pursue a more extensive, in-depth exploration of a specific area, AOTA’s Professional Certificate Program and Micro Credentials will give you the knowledge and skills you need to better serve your clients and advance within the profession.
ba423002-ef7f-499e-8017-2b287dde708a.name: Home Modification & Falls Prevention Micro Credential

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Required Courses: • Occupational Therapy Fall Prevention: Assessment and Intervention Strategies for Community-Dwelling Older Adults • "I've Lived Here for 40 Years Without a Handrail" • Meeting the Psychosocial Needs of Clients • Enabling Design: A Person-Centered Approach • From Inspiration to Installation: The Search for Creative Ideas to Solve Home Mod Challenges • Occupational Therapy’s Role in Assisting a Patient Transition From Hospital to Home. As well as the three Essential Courses.

92354475-de8a-4b35-a152-45a88aaa7703.description: Elevate your practice and get the knowledge you need to be the best OT or OTA that you can be. Whether you’re looking to master a specific set of skills or pursue a more extensive, in-depth exploration of a specific area, AOTA’s Professional Certificate Program and Micro Credentials will give you the knowledge and skills you need to better serve your clients and advance within the profession.
92354475-de8a-4b35-a152-45a88aaa7703.name: Participation, Resilience, and Wellness Micro Credential

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Required Courses are: • Mindfulness for You and Your Clients • Lifestyle Modification Series—Unit 2 – Needs Assessments and Group Leadership • Lifestyle Modification Series—Unit 3 – Routine, Occupational Balance and Health • Lifestyle Modification Series—Unit 4 – Transportation and Occupation • Lifestyle Modification Series—Unit 5 – Stress and Inflammation Management • Lifestyle Modification Series—Unit 6 – Nutrition, Spirituality and Sexuality

ff63ea6b-a51a-4206-81ce-99286ca8dd42.description: Earners of the Falls Prevention badge have successfully demonstrated an understanding that supports evidence-based fall prevention practice among occupational therapy practitioners (OT and OTA). Earners of this badge are skilled at using fall risk assessment strategies and fall prevention interventions for community-dwelling older adults in outpatient settings (including primary care) and home settings. Earners are also well versed in the CDC’s Stopping Accidents, Deaths & Injuries (STEADI).
ff63ea6b-a51a-4206-81ce-99286ca8dd42.name: Falls Prevention

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Complete Occupational Therapy Fall Prevention: Assessment and Intervention Strategies for Community-Dwelling Older Adults  with a score of 75% or greater on the associated exam.

Complete AJOT CE: Effectiveness of Environment-Based Interventions That Address Behavior, Perception, and Falls in People With Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Major Neurocognitive Disorders: A Systematic Review  with a score of 75% or greater on the associated exam.
Complete AJOT CE: Occupational Therapy Fall Prevention Interventions for Community-Dwelling Older Adults: A Systematic Review with a score of 75% or greater on the associated exam.

7a5207a6-0762-4352-ad04-101bf2c561b0.description: Elevate your practice and get the knowledge you need to be the best OT or OTA that you can be. Whether you’re looking to master a specific set of skills or pursue a more extensive, in-depth exploration of a specific area, AOTA’s Professional Certificate Program and Micro Credentials will give you the knowledge and skills you need to better serve your clients and advance within the profession.
7a5207a6-0762-4352-ad04-101bf2c561b0.name: Driving and Community Mobility Micro Credential

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Required Courses: • The Ethical & Professional Obligation to Address Driving When Delivering Occupational Therapy Services • The Impact of Visual Dysfunction on IADLs Including Driving & Community Mobility • Community Mobility: Interventions for Functional Cognition • The IADL of Driving & Community Mobility: Understanding the Client, Occupation and Environment • Occupational Therapy Intervention: Driving & Community Mobility Priorities for Older Adults • Screening & Evaluation of Driving Risk

420bc4b1-d816-4e72-abe0-660b1f5e6447.description: Earners of the Occupational Therapy Driving and Community Mobility Foundation Badge have successfully demonstrated an understanding of driving as an IADL impacted by impairments identified in evaluation of vision, physical ability, and cognition. Earners are familiar with the MODEM model and are able to develop resources to address service gaps and to identify a cost efficient service continuum. In addition, badge earners are able to educate families about transitioning to community mobility.
420bc4b1-d816-4e72-abe0-660b1f5e6447.name: Driving and Community Mobility Foundation Badge

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Completion of: 1) Community Mobility: Interventions for Functional Cognition, 2) Occupational Therapy Intervention: Driving & Community Mobility Priorities for Older Adult, 3) IADL of Driving & Community Mobility: Understanding the Client, Occupation and Environment, 4) The Ethical and Professional Obligation to Address Driving when Delivering OT Services, 3rd ed, 5) Screening and Evaluation Driving Risk, 6) The Impact of Visual Dysfunction on IADLs Including Driving and Community Mobility

b6b5e9d8-a0a5-44f3-91b4-28b5aab64ae7.description: Earners of this micro-credential have demonstrated the ability to address student issues of academic performance and success within the school-based context. Areas of knowledge include: Cognition and learning; literacy; universal design and assistive technology; interprofessional collaborative practice to benefit the student; and use of AOTA document and resources to support practice in school settings. Practitioners have also covered topics dealing with law and policy of school services
b6b5e9d8-a0a5-44f3-91b4-28b5aab64ae7.name: Supporting Academic Achievement in School-Based Practice

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Building a Foundation for School Practice using AOTA Resources The learning environment influences students’ ability to perform and participate in their occupations. Occupational therapy practitioners working in school settings need to understand supporting and barriers impacting student performance within this environment. This course will discuss learning contexts, evaluation and intervention of students using a variety of resources from the AOTA including the OTPF (AOTA, 2020)

Required Essentials Courses must be completed before earning this micro credential: Public Policy Supporting Occupational Therapy in Schools; The Role of Occupational Therapy in Public School Systems of Support; Occupational Therapy Contributions to the Individualized Education Program under IDEA Part B

Interprofessional Collaborative Practices in Multi-tiered Systems of Support in Schools This course highlights the importance of interprofessional collaboration within public education services for Multi-tiered Systems of Support, including referrals and evaluations for special education. Implementation of embedded, collaborative services are shared. Data collection for decision-making is also discussed.

Cognition and Learning Occupational therapy practitioners working in schools understand the essential cognitive and learning that occurs in schools and support student’s participation and success through various indirect and direct service delivery models. This course provides an overview of cognitive development and function.

Assistive Technology, Universal Design for Learning, and School-Based Practice This course provides a foundational understanding and definition of assistive technology and universal design for learning. Information on how these can be embedded into school-based practice is also provided. In addition, the course outlines the role of legislation in supporting the use of technology in school contexts.

Literacy: Handwriting and Written Expression to Enhance Participation Writing as an essential school activity that students use throughout their academic years. As with any learned motor activity, acquisition of handwriting requires educators to provide systematic instruction and practice. When problems arise in writing, a request for an occupational therapy evaluation is made to gather information using formal and informal methods with respect to the student’s performance and contextual support

Literacy: Reading to Enhance Participation. Occupational therapy practitioners support students with reading difficulties using a holistic and participation approach. Although it is essential for practitioners to address the prerequisite skills students need for effective reading, these skills must be related to the goal of increasing meaningful participation in reading activities at school, at home, and in the community.

skills.name: Address cognition and learning through participation
Address reading and written literacy as part of OT intervention

d6f429d1-1d89-436b-a048-c679c3f45b85.description: The holder of this professional certificate has demonstrated the knowledge and skills to work with adults in community based setting who have, or are at risk for loss of occupational participation. The areas of driving, falls prevention, lifestyle choice modification, basic home modification and wellness are addressed through the coursework including assessment, intervention and outcomes. The OT/OTA has demonstrated integration of these related concepts for effective and efficient intervention.
d6f429d1-1d89-436b-a048-c679c3f45b85.name: Home and Community Safety and Driving Professional Certificate

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: A professional certificate is earned after successful completion of three micro credentials comprised of 8-10 contact hours each. This micro credential is the Home Modification and Falls Prevention group
A professional certificate is earned after successful completion of three micro credentials comprised of 8-10 contact hours each. This micro credential is the Driving and Community Mobility group

A professional certificate is earned after successful completion of three micro credentials comprised of 8-10 contact hours each. This micro credential is the Participation, Resilience and Wellness group.
Three Essentials courses are also required. These cover emerging topics within OT practice.

The Integration Course provides the opportunity for the learner to demonstrate that they are able to look at the client holistically to ensure that assessment and intervention address those elements of participation that will maintain quality life and engagement of the client

skills.name: Address safety concerns within the home environment
Generalist level ability to address driving issues
identify safety concerns within the home environment
Provide interventions and environmental modification to reduce fall risk

65f43172-b19f-4ce7-b85f-1edd9b7d71b4.description: Earners of this badge have demonstrated the ability to accurately identify non-compliance with AOTA Criteria and Guidelines and consistently review of APP Provider submissions in a timely manner.
65f43172-b19f-4ce7-b85f-1edd9b7d71b4.name: APP Volunteer Reviewer

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Occupational therapy practitioner licensed and in good standing.
Member of the American Occupational Therapy Association.
Implementation of evidence-based practice to include identification of strength/levels of evidence.
Satisfactory completion of AOTA Approved Provider volunteer training modules.
Satisfactory completion and accurate review of two or more types of Approved Provider Program applications.

skills.name: In-depth knowledge of AOTA APP Criteria and Guidelines

7ee28553-4386-417a-87a2-1a640be651e3.description: This badge is provided to occupational therapists who have completed the AOTA CE course series "Performing a home health start of care." Practitioners are able to confidently perform a start of care for individuals receiving home health services as an outcome of this educational program.
7ee28553-4386-417a-87a2-1a640be651e3.name: Performing Start of Care in Home Health Micro Credential

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Learners must complete 7 courses specifically addressing the role of OT in starting a home health episode of care. The courses include: Module 1: The Start of Care as an Essential Agency Function, Module 2: The Start of Care Process, Module 3: OASIS Data Set and Functional Items, Module 4: OASIS Health Status Items, Module 5: Medication-Related Start of Care Tasks, Module 6 Integrating the Aspects of the Start of Care, Module 7: Add Value and Advocate for OT
Promoting Medication Adherence: An Occupational Therapy Approach to Evaluation and Intervention
Introduction to Functional Cognition
Enhanced Medical Rehabilitation

skills.name: Assessing and identifying immediate health and support needs.
General overall knowledge of OASIS tool

6983680e-2f8c-4326-a92f-78634af0535c.description: The earner of this professional certificate has successfully completed a one year, full time fellowship experience at an AOTA approved institution hosting a specialty experience in Dysphagia care. This experience has taken place face to face at the Mayo clinic in Minnesota.
6983680e-2f8c-4326-a92f-78634af0535c.name: Fellowship Supported Professional Certificate in Dysphagia

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: 54 week paid fellowship experience at the MAYO clinic within the Dysphagia program. AOTA approved experience

skills.name: Preparation as a provider of patient and client care dysphagia.

a7fe9531-345b-4b39-a974-cf6322bb015e.description: This badge is available to you once you have completed the required courses listed below in addition to the Essentials courses for this program. Elevate your practice and get the knowledge you need to be the best OT or OTA that you can be. Whether you’re looking to master a specific set of skills or pursue a more extensive, in-depth exploration of a specific area, AOTA’s Professional Certificate Program and Micro-Credentials will give you the knowledge and skills you need to better serve your cl
a7fe9531-345b-4b39-a974-cf6322bb015e.name: Supporting Social and Emotional Wellbeing in K-12 Micro Credential Badge

issuer.summary: issued by American Occupational Therapy Association

badge_template_activities.title: Required Courses are: •Working with Families K-12 •Occupational Therapy’s Role in Trauma-Informed Schools •Social Emotional Learning and Well-being: Elementary School •Social and Emotional Learning (SEL) and Wellbeing in Middle School •Social Emotional Learning & Well-being: High School & Transition to Adulthood •Social Emotional Learning & Well-being: Specialized Instructional Support Personnel •Interprofessional Practices for Social and Emotional Learning (SEL) and Behavioral Health Teams
